msg.content:
<document>
<title>List of FC Barcelona records and statistics</title>
<content>
Barcelona Statistics at large





![](image)Lionel Messi, pictured in 2018, is Barcelona's all-time top scorer, with 672 goals in all competitions.[1]
Futbol Club Barcelona is a professional association football club based in Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain. Founded by a group of Swiss, German, English and Catalan footballers led by Joan Gamper, the club has become a symbol of Catalan culture and Catalanism, hence the motto *"Més que un club"* (More than a club). The official Barça anthem is the "Cant del Barça", written by Jaume Picas and Josep Maria Espinàs.[2] Unlike many other football clubs, the *socis*, who are the members and supporters of the club, own and operate Barcelona. It is the world's fourth richest football club in terms of revenue, with an annual turnover of €582.1 million in the 2020–21 season.[3]


Barcelona played its first friendly match on 8 December 1899 against the English colony in Barcelona in the old velodrome in Bonanova.[4] Initially, Barcelona played against other local clubs in various Catalan tournaments. In 1929, the club became one of the founding members of La Liga, Spain's first national league, and has since achieved the distinction of being one of only three clubs to have never been relegated, along with Real Madrid and Athletic Bilbao. Barcelona is also the only European club to have played continental football every season since 1955. They hold a long-standing rivalry with Real Madrid, with matches between the two teams referred to as "El Clásico" (*El Clàssic* in Catalan). Matches against city rivals Espanyol are known as the "Derbi barceloní".


Barcelona has amassed various records in regional, domestic and continental tournaments since its founding. During the time the club played in regional competitions until the end of the Catalan championship in 1940, it won a record 23 titles from a possible 38. In 2009, Barcelona achieved an unprecedented sextuple by winning La Liga, the Copa del Rey, the UEFA Champions League, the Supercopa de España, the UEFA Super Cup and the FIFA Club World Cup in one calendar year. Additionally, Barça has won the coveted continental treble, consisting of La Liga, the Copa del Rey and the UEFA Champions League in the aforementioned 2009 and again 2015, becoming the first European club to have won the treble twice.[5]


Barcelona has signed several high-profile players, setting the world record in transfer fees on three occasions with the purchase of Johan Cruyff from Ajax in 1973, Diego Maradona from Boca Juniors in 1982 and Ronaldo from PSV Eindhoven in 1996. The club's players have received seven FIFA World Player of the Year awards, twelve Ballon d'Or awards, three UEFA Men's Player of the Year awards and eight European Golden Shoe awards.




## Honours[edit]


FC Barcelona won their first trophy in 1902 when they lifted the Copa Macaya, which was the predecessor to the Catalan Championship. The club won the Catalan Championship a record 23 times during the 40-year span of the tournament.[6]


When the national league was established in 1929, the importance of the regional league declined, and it was abandoned in 1940. From then on, Barcelona did not participate in regional competitions until the establishment of the Copa Catalunya in 1993, a cup they have won a record nine times.[6]


They are the most successful football club in Spain, having won a total of 77 domestic titles: 27 La Liga, a record 31 Copa del Rey, a record 14 Supercopa de España, a record three Copa Eva Duarte[note 1] and a record two Copa de la Liga.


The club is also one of the most successful clubs in international club football, having won 22 official trophies in total, 14 of which are UEFA competitions and 8 recognised by FIFA. Barcelona has won five UEFA Champions League titles, a record four UEFA Cup Winners' Cup titles, a record three Inter-Cities Fairs Cup titles (non-UEFA), a shared record of two Latin Cup titles, a shared record of five UEFA Super Cup titles and three FIFA Club World Cup titles. They are also second to Real Madrid in terms of overall official titles 99-101.[7][8]

	+ ![Spain](image) Víctor Valdés went 896 minutes without conceding a goal in all competitions in the 2011–12 season (from the 22nd minute of the 5th game to the 20th minute of the 12th game). Six games of the Spanish League and three Champions League games were played without conceding a goal.
	+ ![Spain](image) Miguel Reina went 824 minutes without conceding a goal in the Spanish League in the 1972–73 season (from the 53rd minute of the 14th game to the 67th minute of the 23rd game).

	+ ![Spain](image) Víctor Valdés played 535 official games of which he maintained a clean sheet in 237 games, or 44.3% of the matches. The former record was held by ![Spain](image) Andoni Zubizarreta who played 410 official games of which he maintained a clean sheet in 173 games, or 42.2% of the matches.

	+ **26** kept by ![Germany](image) Marc-André ter Stegen in 2022–23.

	+ ![Germany](image) Marc-André ter Stegen in 2022–23 with an average of **0.47** goals (**18** goals in **38** games).
* Best unbeaten start:[76]
	+ **754** minutes by ![Chile](image) Claudio Bravo in 2014–15.

	+ Won **10–1** over Gimnàstic de Tarragona in 1949–50.
* Biggest away win in La Liga (**record**):[91]
	+ **0–8** over Las Palmas in 1959–60.
	+ **0–8** over Almería in 2010–11.
	+ **0–8** over Córdoba in 2014–15.
	+ **0–8** over Deportivo La Coruña in 2015–16.
* Biggest defeat in La Liga:[102]
	+ Lost **12–1** to Athletic Bilbao in 1930–31.
* Most consecutive matches as leader of La Liga:[103]
	+ **59** matchdays (from matchday 1 of the 2012–13 season to matchday 21 of the 2013–14 season).


### International[edit]


* Only team to have appeared in every year of the continental competition:[91]
	+ Barcelona has participated since the inception in 1955.
* Highest win in European competitions at home games:[91]
	+ **8–0** over Apollon Limassol (Cyprus) in 1982 and 8–0 over Púchov (Slovakia) in 2003.
* Highest win in European competition at away games:[91]
	+ **0–7** over Hapoel Be'er Sheva (Israel) in the 1995–96 UEFA Cup.
* Most consecutive wins in the UEFA Champions League:[91]
	+ **11** wins during the 2002–03 season.
* Most goals in a UEFA Champions League season:[91]
	+ **45** goals during the 1999–2000 season.
* Most FIFA World Cup Golden Balls won by the players from a single club:
	+ **4** – ![Netherlands](image) Johan Cruyff won in 1974, ![Brazil](image) Romário in 1994, and ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi in 2014 and 2022.
* Most FIFA Club World Cup Golden Balls won by the players from a single club:
	+ **4** – Deco (won in 2006), ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi (won in 2009 and 2011), and ![Uruguay](image) Luis Suárez (won in 2015).
* Most FIFA/France Football Ballons d'Or won by the players from a single club:[78]
	+ **12** – ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi (won in 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012, 2015 and 2019), ![Netherlands](image) Johan Cruyff (won in 1973 and 1974), ![Spain](image) Luis Suárez (won in 1960), ![Bulgaria](image) Hristo Stoichkov (won in 1994), ![Brazil](image) Rivaldo (won in 1999), and ![Brazil](image) Ronaldinho (won in 2005).
* Most European Golden Shoe awards won by the players from a single club:
	+ **8** – ![Brazil](image) Ronaldo (won in 1997), ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi (won in 2010, 2012, 2013, 2017, 2018 and 2019), and ![Uruguay](image) Luis Suárez (won in 2016).
* Only team that have been represented by final three contenders at a FIFA Ballon d'Or Gala:
	+ In **2010**, the final three contenders were Barcelona players ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi, ![Spain](image) Andrés Iniesta and ![Spain](image) Xavi.
* Only team of which youth academy has been represented by final three contenders at a FIFA Ballon d'Or Gala:
	+ In **2010**, the final three contenders were Barcelona youth academy players ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi, ![Spain](image) Andrés Iniesta and ![Spain](image) Xavi.
* Only team that have collected all the awards (Golden Boot, Golden Ball, Silver Ball, Bronze Ball and Fair Play award) at a single FIFA Club World Cup:[104]
	+ In **2015**, ![Uruguay](image) Luis Suárez won the Golden Ball and the Golden Boot, ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi won the Silver Ball, ![Spain](image) Andrés Iniesta won the Bronze Ball and Barcelona was awarded the Fair Play award.


### All competitions[edit]


* First ever team to win the treble twice in Europe:[105][106]
	+ Barcelona won the Spanish Cup, Spanish League and the UEFA Champions League in 2008–09 and in 2014–15.
* Year with most titles:[107]
	+ Only Spanish football team to ever win six titles in a year and completing the sextuple by winning (in 2009): Spanish Cup, Spanish League, European Cup, Spanish Super Cup, European Super Cup and FIFA Club World Cup.
* Team with most Spanish titles: **109**.[91]
* Spanish club with most official titles: **124**.[91]
* Season with most titles (Spanish football record):[91]
	+ Five championship titles in 1951–52: La Liga, Copa del Rey, the Latin Cup, Copa Eva Duarte and Copa Martini & Rossi.
* Biggest win in any competition:[91]
	+ **18–0**, in the Copa Macaya: Tarragona 0–18 Barcelona in 1901.
* Biggest win in a Friendly match:[91]
	+ **20–1**, Smilde (Netherlands) 1–20 Barcelona in 1992.
* Longest unbeaten run in all competitive matches:[108]
	+ **39** games in the 2015–16 season
* Longest winning run in competitive matches:[91]
	+ **19** games in both domestic and international matches during the 2005–06 season: 13 in the league, 3 in the Champions League, 2 in the Spanish cup and 1 in the Catalan Cup.
* Most consecutive away wins:[91]
	+ **13** games during the 2008–09 season: 8 in the league, 3 in the Champions League and 2 in the Copa del Rey (also a Spanish football record).
* Longest scoring run in all competitions:[92]
	+ **44** games: **36** in league between game 9 (22 November 1942) of the 1942–43 season and game 18 (6 February 1944) of the 1943–44 season, and **8** Cup games in 1943.
* 2nd most goals in a season – all competitions:[1]
	+ **190** in the 2011–12
* Most goals scored by players from the youth system:[1]
	+ Of the **190** goals scored in the 2011–12 season, **150** were scored by players from Barcelona's youth system (also a Spanish football record).
* Most scorers in official matches in a season:[1]
	+ In the 2010–11 season, **23** Barcelona players scored at least one goal in official competitions (also a Spanish football record).
* Most victories in a season:[74]
	+ **50** in the 2014–15 season, out of a possible 60 games (also a Spanish Football record).
* Most matches unbeaten by a Spanish team – all competitions:[1]
	+ **34** in the 2015–16 season
* Most consecutive away wins:[74]
	+ **13** games during the 2008–09 season.

<document>
<title>List of FC Barcelona records and statistics</title>
<content>
Barcelona Statistics at large





![](image)Lionel Messi, pictured in 2018, is Barcelona's all-time top scorer, with 672 goals in all competitions.[1]
Futbol Club Barcelona is a professional association football club based in Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain. Founded by a group of Swiss, German, English and Catalan footballers led by Joan Gamper, the club has become a symbol of Catalan culture and Catalanism, hence the motto *"Més que un club"* (More than a club). The official Barça anthem is the "Cant del Barça", written by Jaume Picas and Josep Maria Espinàs.[2] Unlike many other football clubs, the *socis*, who are the members and supporters of the club, own and operate Barcelona. It is the world's fourth richest football club in terms of revenue, with an annual turnover of €582.1 million in the 2020–21 season.[3]


Barcelona played its first friendly match on 8 December 1899 against the English colony in Barcelona in the old velodrome in Bonanova.[4] Initially, Barcelona played against other local clubs in various Catalan tournaments. In 1929, the club became one of the founding members of La Liga, Spain's first national league, and has since achieved the distinction of being one of only three clubs to have never been relegated, along with Real Madrid and Athletic Bilbao. Barcelona is also the only European club to have played continental football every season since 1955. They hold a long-standing rivalry with Real Madrid, with matches between the two teams referred to as "El Clásico" (*El Clàssic* in Catalan). Matches against city rivals Espanyol are known as the "Derbi barceloní".


Barcelona has amassed various records in regional, domestic and continental tournaments since its founding. During the time the club played in regional competitions until the end of the Catalan championship in 1940, it won a record 23 titles from a possible 38. In 2009, Barcelona achieved an unprecedented sextuple by winning La Liga, the Copa del Rey, the UEFA Champions League, the Supercopa de España, the UEFA Super Cup and the FIFA Club World Cup in one calendar year. Additionally, Barça has won the coveted continental treble, consisting of La Liga, the Copa del Rey and the UEFA Champions League in the aforementioned 2009 and again 2015, becoming the first European club to have won the treble twice.[5]


Barcelona has signed several high-profile players, setting the world record in transfer fees on three occasions with the purchase of Johan Cruyff from Ajax in 1973, Diego Maradona from Boca Juniors in 1982 and Ronaldo from PSV Eindhoven in 1996. The club's players have received seven FIFA World Player of the Year awards, twelve Ballon d'Or awards, three UEFA Men's Player of the Year awards and eight European Golden Shoe awards.




## Honours[edit]


FC Barcelona won their first trophy in 1902 when they lifted the Copa Macaya, which was the predecessor to the Catalan Championship. The club won the Catalan Championship a record 23 times during the 40-year span of the tournament.[6]


When the national league was established in 1929, the importance of the regional league declined, and it was abandoned in 1940. From then on, Barcelona did not participate in regional competitions until the establishment of the Copa Catalunya in 1993, a cup they have won a record nine times.[6]


They are the most successful football club in Spain, having won a total of 77 domestic titles: 27 La Liga, a record 31 Copa del Rey, a record 14 Supercopa de España, a record three Copa Eva Duarte[note 1] and a record two Copa de la Liga.


The club is also one of the most successful clubs in international club football, having won 22 official trophies in total, 14 of which are UEFA competitions and 8 recognised by FIFA. Barcelona has won five UEFA Champions League titles, a record four UEFA Cup Winners' Cup titles, a record three Inter-Cities Fairs Cup titles (non-UEFA), a shared record of two Latin Cup titles, a shared record of five UEFA Super Cup titles and three FIFA Club World Cup titles. They are also second to Real Madrid in terms of overall official titles 99-101.[7][8]

* The following Barcelona players have won the Ricardo Zamora Trophy for lowest "goals-to-games" ratio in La Liga (Antoni Ramallets and Víctor Valdés have each won the trophy a record five times for Barcelona):[1]
	+ ![Spain](image) Juan Zambudio Velasco: (1) 1947–48
	+ ![Spain](image) Antoni Ramallets: (5) 1951–52, 1955–56, 1956–57, 1958–59, 1959–60
	+ ![Spain](image) José Manuel Pesudo: (1) 1965–66
	+ ![Spain](image) Salvador Sadurní: (3) 1968–69, 1973–74, 1974–75
	+ ![Spain](image) Miguel Reina: (1) 1972–73
	+ ![Spain](image) Pedro María Artola: (1) 1977–78
	+ ![Spain](image) Javier Urruticoechea: (1) 1983–84
	+ ![Spain](image) Andoni Zubizarreta: (1) 1986–87
	+ ![Spain](image) Víctor Valdés: (5) 2004–05, 2008–09, 2009–10, 2010–11, 2011–12
	+ ![Chile](image) Claudio Bravo: (1) 2014–15
	+ ![Germany](image) Marc-André ter Stegen: (1) 2022–23
* Longest period without conceding a goal:[1]
	+ ![Spain](image) Víctor Valdés went 896 minutes without conceding a goal in all competitions in the 2011–12 season (from the 22nd minute of the 5th game to the 20th minute of the 12th game). Six games of the Spanish League and three Champions League games were played without conceding a goal.
	+ ![Spain](image) Miguel Reina went 824 minutes without conceding a goal in the Spanish League in the 1972–73 season (from the 53rd minute of the 14th game to the 67th minute of the 23rd game).
* Most clean sheets:
	+ ![Spain](image) Víctor Valdés played 535 official games of which he maintained a clean sheet in 237 games, or 44.3% of the matches. The former record was held by ![Spain](image) Andoni Zubizarreta who played 410 official games of which he maintained a clean sheet in 173 games, or 42.2% of the matches.
* Most clean sheets in a season:[74]
	+ **33** in 2014–15: **23** kept by ![Chile](image) Claudio Bravo (all in La Liga), **10** kept by ![Germany](image) Marc-André ter Stegen **6** in Champions League and **4** in Copa del Rey.
* Most clean sheets registered by a keeper in a La Liga season:[75]
	+ **26** kept by ![Germany](image) Marc-André ter Stegen in 2022–23.
* Goalkeeper with best average goals conceded in history:[75]
	+ ![Germany](image) Marc-André ter Stegen in 2022–23 with an average of **0.47** goals (**18** goals in **38** games).
* Best unbeaten start:[76]
	+ **754** minutes by ![Chile](image) Claudio Bravo in 2014–15.

## Managerial records[edit]


See also: List of FC Barcelona managers

* First full-time manager: ![England](image) John Barrow.[89]
* Most seasons as coach: ![England](image) Jack Greenwell, nine years in two spells from 1917 to 1924 and from 1931 to 1933.[1]
* Most consecutive seasons as coach: ![Netherlands](image) Johan Cruyff, managed the club for eight years between 1988 and 1996.[1]
* Most matches undefeated in a La Liga season: **37** ![Spain](image) Pep Guardiola in 2009–10 season and ![Spain](image) Ernesto Valverde in 2017–18 season[1]
* Most consecutive matches undefeated in a La Liga season: **36** ![Spain](image) Ernesto Valverde, between Matchdays 1 and 34 (matchday 34 was played after matchday 36) in 2017–18 season[1]
* Most consecutive away matches undefeated in a La Liga season: **16** ![Spain](image) Pep Guardiola, between 29 August 2010 (Matchday 1) and 23 April 2011 (Matchday 33) in 2010–11 season[1]
* Most consecutive away matches won in La Liga: **10** ![Spain](image) Pep Guardiola, between 29 August 2010 (Matchday 1) and 29 January 2011 (Matchday 21) in 2010-11 season[1]
* Most trophies won as coach: ![Spain](image) Pep Guardiola, 14 titles out of 19 possible between August 2008 and May 2012.[1]
* Coaches who won the treble:[90]
	+ ![Spain](image) Pep Guardiola in 2008–09.
	+ ![Spain](image) Luis Enrique in 2014–15.

## Team records[edit]


Barcelona's team records include the following:[91]



### La Liga[edit]


#### Points[edit]


* Most points in a season:[92]
	+ **100** points in the 2012–13 season (La Liga record).
* The team with most points at the end of the first half of the league:[93]
	+ **55** points during the 2012–13 season (La Liga record).
* The team with most points at the end of the second half of the league:[91]
	+ **50** points during the 2009–10 season.
* Maximum difference over the runner up:[93]
	+ **15** points over Real Madrid in the 2012–13 season (La Liga record).


#### Goals[edit]


![](image)A chart showing the progress of Barcelona's cumulative goal difference in La Liga
* Most away goals scored in a League season:
	+ 52 goals scored in the 2012–13 season.[91][94]
* Season with the best goal difference in a League season:
	+ +89 in 2014–15 season.[91][95]
* Season with most goals scored in League matches:
	+ In 2016–17 season, the club scored a total number of 116 goals in 38 games.[91][94]
* Season with fewest goals scored in League matches:
	+ The club scored a total number of 32 goals in 22 games in the 1939–40 season.[91][96]
* First Spanish team to score in all away games in a La Liga season:
	+ In 2010–11 season, 19 games[97]
* Season with fewest goals conceded in League matches:
	+ The club conceded a total number of 18 goals in 30 games in the 1968–69 season.[91][98]
	+ The club conceded a total number of 20 goals in 38 in the 2022–23 season.
* Season with most goals conceded:
	+ The club conceded a total number of 66 goals in 26 games in the 1941–42 season.[91][99]
* Most goals scored in a calendar year – all competitions:[1]
	+ 180 goals in 2015


#### Streaks[edit]


* Consecutive La Liga titles:[91][100]
	+ Won **4** championship titles: 1990–91, 1991–92, 1992–93, 1993–94 seasons.
* Longest consecutive unbeaten matches in La Liga (**record**):[91]
	+ **43** games, 2016–17 and 2017–18 season.
* Longest consecutive unbeaten matches at home in La Liga:[91]
	+ **67** games from game 25 of 1972–73 season to game 21 1976–77 season.
* Longest consecutive unbeaten matches away from home in La Liga (**record**):[91][101]
	+ **23** games (14 February 2010 to 30 April 2011)
* Longest consecutive unbeaten matches in La Liga from first game:[91]
	+ **36** first games of 2017–18 season.
* Longest winning run in La Liga (**joint record**):[91]
	+ **16** games in the 2010–11 season.
* Longest winning run at home in La Liga:[91]
	+ **39** games between game 22 of the 1957–58 season to game 8 of the 1960–61 season.
* Longest winning run in away matches in La Liga:[92]
	+ **12** games (1 May 2010 to 12 February 2011)
* Longest consecutive scoring in La Liga (**record**):[92]
	+ **72** games (4 February 2012 to 19 October 2013)
* Longest consecutive scoring at home in La Liga:[91]
	+ **88** games between game 22 of the 1951–52 season to game 18 of the 1957–58 season.
* Longest consecutive scoring in away matches in La Liga (**record**):[92]
	+ **26** games, from game 35 (1 May 2010) of the 2009–10 season until game 12 (6 November 2011) of the 2011–12 season.
* Most consecutive wins and best away start in La Liga (**record**):[91]
	+ **10** victories in the 2010–11 season.
* Biggest home win in La Liga:[91]
	+ Won **10–1** over Gimnàstic de Tarragona in 1949–50.
* Biggest away win in La Liga (**record**):[91]
	+ **0–8** over Las Palmas in 1959–60.
	+ **0–8** over Almería in 2010–11.
	+ **0–8** over Córdoba in 2014–15.
	+ **0–8** over Deportivo La Coruña in 2015–16.
* Biggest defeat in La Liga:[102]
	+ Lost **12–1** to Athletic Bilbao in 1930–31.
* Most consecutive matches as leader of La Liga:[103]
	+ **59** matchdays (from matchday 1 of the 2012–13 season to matchday 21 of the 2013–14 season).


### International[edit]


* Only team to have appeared in every year of the continental competition:[91]
	+ Barcelona has participated since the inception in 1955.
* Highest win in European competitions at home games:[91]
	+ **8–0** over Apollon Limassol (Cyprus) in 1982 and 8–0 over Púchov (Slovakia) in 2003.
* Highest win in European competition at away games:[91]
	+ **0–7** over Hapoel Be'er Sheva (Israel) in the 1995–96 UEFA Cup.
* Most consecutive wins in the UEFA Champions League:[91]
	+ **11** wins during the 2002–03 season.
* Most goals in a UEFA Champions League season:[91]
	+ **45** goals during the 1999–2000 season.
* Most FIFA World Cup Golden Balls won by the players from a single club:
	+ **4** – ![Netherlands](image) Johan Cruyff won in 1974, ![Brazil](image) Romário in 1994, and ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi in 2014 and 2022.
* Most FIFA Club World Cup Golden Balls won by the players from a single club:
	+ **4** – Deco (won in 2006), ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi (won in 2009 and 2011), and ![Uruguay](image) Luis Suárez (won in 2015).
* Most FIFA/France Football Ballons d'Or won by the players from a single club:[78]
	+ **12** – ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi (won in 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012, 2015 and 2019), ![Netherlands](image) Johan Cruyff (won in 1973 and 1974), ![Spain](image) Luis Suárez (won in 1960), ![Bulgaria](image) Hristo Stoichkov (won in 1994), ![Brazil](image) Rivaldo (won in 1999), and ![Brazil](image) Ronaldinho (won in 2005).
* Most European Golden Shoe awards won by the players from a single club:
	+ **8** – ![Brazil](image) Ronaldo (won in 1997), ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi (won in 2010, 2012, 2013, 2017, 2018 and 2019), and ![Uruguay](image) Luis Suárez (won in 2016).
* Only team that have been represented by final three contenders at a FIFA Ballon d'Or Gala:
	+ In **2010**, the final three contenders were Barcelona players ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi, ![Spain](image) Andrés Iniesta and ![Spain](image) Xavi.
* Only team of which youth academy has been represented by final three contenders at a FIFA Ballon d'Or Gala:
	+ In **2010**, the final three contenders were Barcelona youth academy players ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi, ![Spain](image) Andrés Iniesta and ![Spain](image) Xavi.
* Only team that have collected all the awards (Golden Boot, Golden Ball, Silver Ball, Bronze Ball and Fair Play award) at a single FIFA Club World Cup:[104]
	+ In **2015**, ![Uruguay](image) Luis Suárez won the Golden Ball and the Golden Boot, ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi won the Silver Ball, ![Spain](image) Andrés Iniesta won the Bronze Ball and Barcelona was awarded the Fair Play award.


### All competitions[edit]


* First ever team to win the treble twice in Europe:[105][106]
	+ Barcelona won the Spanish Cup, Spanish League and the UEFA Champions League in 2008–09 and in 2014–15.
* Year with most titles:[107]
	+ Only Spanish football team to ever win six titles in a year and completing the sextuple by winning (in 2009): Spanish Cup, Spanish League, European Cup, Spanish Super Cup, European Super Cup and FIFA Club World Cup.
* Team with most Spanish titles: **109**.[91]
* Spanish club with most official titles: **124**.[91]
* Season with most titles (Spanish football record):[91]
	+ Five championship titles in 1951–52: La Liga, Copa del Rey, the Latin Cup, Copa Eva Duarte and Copa Martini & Rossi.
* Biggest win in any competition:[91]
	+ **18–0**, in the Copa Macaya: Tarragona 0–18 Barcelona in 1901.
* Biggest win in a Friendly match:[91]
	+ **20–1**, Smilde (Netherlands) 1–20 Barcelona in 1992.
* Longest unbeaten run in all competitive matches:[108]
	+ **39** games in the 2015–16 season
* Longest winning run in competitive matches:[91]
	+ **19** games in both domestic and international matches during the 2005–06 season: 13 in the league, 3 in the Champions League, 2 in the Spanish cup and 1 in the Catalan Cup.
* Most consecutive away wins:[91]
	+ **13** games during the 2008–09 season: 8 in the league, 3 in the Champions League and 2 in the Copa del Rey (also a Spanish football record).
* Longest scoring run in all competitions:[92]
	+ **44** games: **36** in league between game 9 (22 November 1942) of the 1942–43 season and game 18 (6 February 1944) of the 1943–44 season, and **8** Cup games in 1943.
* 2nd most goals in a season – all competitions:[1]
	+ **190** in the 2011–12
* Most goals scored by players from the youth system:[1]
	+ Of the **190** goals scored in the 2011–12 season, **150** were scored by players from Barcelona's youth system (also a Spanish football record).
* Most scorers in official matches in a season:[1]
	+ In the 2010–11 season, **23** Barcelona players scored at least one goal in official competitions (also a Spanish football record).
* Most victories in a season:[74]
	+ **50** in the 2014–15 season, out of a possible 60 games (also a Spanish Football record).
* Most matches unbeaten by a Spanish team – all competitions:[1]
	+ **34** in the 2015–16 season
* Most consecutive away wins:[74]
	+ **13** games during the 2008–09 season.

5. Josep Samitier (184 goals) - Born in Barcelona, Spain

1. Rosario, Argentina
2. León, Spain
3. Salto, Uruguay
4. Budapest, Hungary
5. Barcelona, Spain
